sn9.13:4.1: Now at that time several mendicants were staying in the Kosalan lands in a certain forest grove. They were restless, insolent, fickle, gossipy, loose tongued, unmindful, lacking situational awareness and samādhi, with straying minds and undisciplined faculties.
sn9.13:4.2: The deity haunting that forest had compassion for those mendicants, and wanted what’s best for them. So they approached those mendicants wanting to stir them up,
sn9.13:5.5: Knowing that the world was impermanent
sn9.13:5.6: they made an end of suffering.
sn9.13:6.1: But now they’ve made themselves hard to look after,
sn9.13:6.3: They eat and eat and then lie down,
sn9.13:6.4: unconscious in the homes of others.
sn9.13:7.1: Having raised my cupped palms to the Saṅgha,
sn9.13:7.2: I speak here only about certain people.
sn9.13:7.4: just like those who have passed away.
sn9.13:9.1: Stirred up by that deity, those mendicants came to their senses.
